snippet: The persistent competition with Rick Santorum and Newt Gingrich is forcing Mitt Romney to guard his right flank instead of directing his attention to President Obama.
abstract: News analysis; surge of caucus victories by Rick Santorum and lingering feud with Newt Gingrich are forcing Mitt Romney to expend his energy on attacks from the right, rather than pursuing his long-term goal of positioning himself against Pres Obama; latest defeats, along with a palpable dearth of enthusiasm surrounding Romney's campaign, have highlighted several potential weaknesses for him as a general election candidate.

byline.contributor: Kirk Johnson contributed reporting from Denver, Ashley Parker from Atlanta and Jim Rutenberg from New York.

lead_paragraph: The persistent competition with Rick Santorum and Newt Gingrich is forcing Mitt Romney to guard his right flank instead of directing his attention to President Obama.

headline.main: Romney Faces Rebels on the Right and Softness in the Middle
headline.print_headline: Romney Faces Rebels on the Right and Softness in the Middle
